linkTarget.anchoringText: Oil Down Tos (ODTs) were logged by the wells drilled through the X1000, X2000 and X3000 reservoirs as shown in table 1. The X1000 top structure map and geological cross section are as shown in Figure 1 and 2 below.

image-wrap.label: Figure 1
image-wrap.caption: X1000 Top Structure Map showing well penetrations

formatted-caption.caption-text: X1000 Top Structure Map showing well penetrations

linkTarget.anchoringText: Oil Down Tos (ODTs) were logged by the wells drilled through the X1000, X2000 and X3000 reservoirs as shown in table 1. The X1000 top structure map and geological cross section are as shown in Figure 1 and 2 below.

image-wrap.label: Figure 2
image-wrap.caption: Cross section showing stacked reservoir system in Yoko Field

formatted-caption.caption-text: Cross section showing stacked reservoir system in Yoko Field

linkTarget.anchoringText: A pressure trend line was established and used in this analysis for all subject reservoirs. Plots of pressure and hydrostatic trend lines (Figure 3) show an intersection in cleaner sands and minor variations in shaly sands.

image-wrap.label: Figure 3
image-wrap.caption: A plot of pressure data and hydrostatic trend lines

formatted-caption.caption-text: A plot of pressure data and hydrostatic trend lines

linkTarget.anchoringText: This stage involved the use of analogue Hydrocarbon columns (HC) from a matured field with similar structural settings to bench mark the possible HC columns in the subject field (Yoko). The maximum HC columns thicknesses as seen in the analogue field were plotted with average HC columns that were encountered by wells (Figure 4).

This method was principally based on the sealing integrity of two critical faults ‘‘A & C’’ (Figure 5) that control hydrocarbon culminations in the target reservoirs. The STAR (Stochastic Trap Analysis and Risking) tool in Petrel was deployed to carry out the analysis using the Juxtapositions option due to the reservoirs stacking patterns.
The STAR scenario was used to evaluate the contacts based on the Net-to-Gross models for different reservoirs (Figure 6).

image-wrap.label: Figure 6
image-wrap.caption: Yoko field X1000Fault Seal Analysis (STAR Scenario) and Results

formatted-caption.caption-text: Yoko field X1000Fault Seal Analysis (STAR Scenario) and Results

linkTarget.anchoringText: This method was used to predict contacts in the X1000, X2000 and X3000 reservoirs using the amplitude attribute from updated time and depth structure maps. The X1000 reservoir showed conformity of amplitude to structure (Figure 7).

image-wrap.label: Figure 7
image-wrap.caption: X1000 Acoustic Impedance Amplitude vs. Depth

formatted-caption.caption-text: X1000 Acoustic Impedance Amplitude vs. Depth

linkTarget.anchoringText: The water-cut match criterion was not critical for the X1000 reservoir since no water production has been observed from any of the wells. The simulation was constrained on liquid production. The P50, P90 and P10 history match on reservoir is shown in (Figure 8).

image-wrap.label: Figure 8
image-wrap.caption: X1000 History Matching Attempted by assuming ODT is OWC

formatted-caption.caption-text: X1000 History Matching Attempted by assuming ODT is OWC

image-wrap.caption: Cross section shoning stacked reserwoir system in Yoko Field

formatted-caption.caption-text: Cross section shoning stacked reserwoir system in Yoko Field
